Award.AbstractNarration:
Rohde will continue his investigations of conformal mappings generated by the Loewner differential equation, and will investigate the conformal geometry of random surfaces, particularly random planar maps such as the Benjamini-Schramm Uniformly Infinite Planar Triangulation. One aspect of Rohde's research is to understand similarities and differences between the deterministic and the stochastic Loewner equation, such as trace properties and their dependence on the regularity of the driving term. The Loewner equation is closely related to the "Zipper-algorithm" of Kuhnau and Marshall, and to conformal welding. Another aspect of Rohde's research is to prove convergence of this welding algorithm, and to study generalized weldings corresponding to non-simple curves. Rohde's research also explores the analytic foundations of the emerging theory of random maps and random Riemann surfaces, such as the type problem.

What is the shape of a large molecule such as DNA? How does water percolate through soil? What are the patterns of spin-alignments in ferro-magnets? These problems are too complex to allow for a precise and simple mathematical answer. Even much simpler mathematical models, proposed by chemists and physicists, were out of reach of mathematicians for decades. This changed in 1999 with the invention of the Schramm-Loewner Evolution SLE, the Loewner equation driven by one-dimensional Brownian motion. The last decade has witnessed tremendous progress on old mathematical problems and even provided physicists with new and unexpected insights, as well as furthering interactions between probabilists, mathematical physicists, and complex analysts. Rohde's research aims at foundational questions of this emerging theory. Specifically, he is working on path properties of solutions of the Loewner equation in both the deterministic and probabilistic setting, and he is working towards an understanding of the large-scale behavior of random sphere-triangulations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under this grant, the PI continued his investigations of path properties of the deterministic Loewner equation as well as the stochastic Schramm-Loewner Evolution SLE. In this theory, the size of a curve in the upper half plane is measured by the half-plane capacity, which is defined implicitely as the derivative of a conformal map. With Carto Wong, he gave a geometric interpretation of this important quantity. He showed (jointly with Fredrik Johansson-Viklund and Carto Wong) that SLE traces depend continuously on the parameter kappa.With Joan Lind, he developed the notion of Loewner curvature and showed an analog of the Schur theorem, namely that curves ofsufficiently small Loewner curvature are simple. With James Gill he gave a geometric proof of a result of Mateo, Orobitg and Verderaregarding the bi-Lipschitz property of solutions to the Beltrami equation with Hoelder continuous Beltrami coefficient.With Matthew Badger, James Gill and Tatiana Toro he found the sharp decay rate for the dilatitation of a quasiconformal map to guaranteethe rectifiability of the image of a co-dimension one space.With Dapeng Zhan, he proved that the conformal welding of SLE traces is symmetric under inversion. During the life of the award, three graduate studentsreceived their Ph.D. under the PI's direction, and the PI co-organized nine workshops and conferences.
